spacekadt
Ok Crow - I've often wondered and after seeing something elsewhere, I'm finally asking.

Where's the line on abbreviations?

Things like "IMO", "ofc", "obv", "afk", "btw", "wtf" or tons of other abbreviations/acronyms are generally accepted internet culture and aren't generally considered "text speak" unless there's a HUGE abundance of them all thrown together.

However, I've seen people get warned for the use of just one or two not QUITE so standard abbreviations and have their posts edited when they otherwise make valid points and are having an actual conversation. It's faster, it's easier and it's generally understood. And for christ's sake, the game is Die2Nite, not DieTonight.

On the other hand (look! there's one now that I initially typed "OTOH" for), some people do constantly misspell words and blame it on using their phone, despite it being part of the same rule. (And hell, the posts where people don't even TRY to spell right drive me 100 times crazier than the occasional abbreviation - "cru" instead of "crew"? Really? And I'm sure I'm not the only one.)

Text-speak (SMS language) is not accepted as it is not appreciated on forums. Take a little care over your spelling, and re-read what you are posting! Use a spellchecker to minimise mistakes!

Not only are these posts not warned, some of the people (yes, people, not person) behind them are held up as pillars of the community.

I'm not saying typos are bad and typos should be warned... god knows we all make them. Repeatedly. But there's typos, then there's just not caring about it.

Is there any chance of relaxing this rule a little bit so it can be a little more of a judgement call (and fair, at that)? I'm just not sure a single abbreviation in a 4-5 paragraph post is worth editing/warning someone.

ristoril
Dear Crow,

What have we learned? Here's some things I'd suggest:

*Don't do any updates on Friday. Seriously. This isn't 1997. Everyone at MT should know better than to make code changes of any sort right before a weekend.

*Communicate. How did this go for two days with literally no official word from MT about it? Not even a quick forum post along the lines of, "we're aware of the problem, we're taking steps to address it."

*Do your job. People are paying for this game and it runs 7 days a week. Someone should be working every day, and if something goes wrong *everyone* that works for this needs to be called in immediately. At my job I routinely have to drop everything and go address unforeseen issues. You should, too.

*Execute your contingency plans. The help says that you have the ability to quarantine towns. Do it. If you can't do it, don't lie about your ability to do it.

*Make amends for your mistakes. This distinction/ability/whatever is poor medicine. I appreciate the gesture, but seriously, I blew money I could have spent on other things playing this town. I spend more on this game than an animated MMORPG with stable servers and 24/7 help costs. I was seriously questioning this allocation of funds when y'all tried the meta cap. Luckily you saw that as the mistake it was. I'm hoping you'll come to the realization after some reflection that it's wrong to take someone's money and not give them what you promised to give them.

Pay attention to that. You took my money and then you didn't give me what you promised in exchange for that money. I gave you that money in good faith expecting to be provided access to this game. You didn't even make a good faith effort to keep me informed of what was happening, let alone give me access to the game.

You guys didn't do your jobs. You failed at your jobs. The power didn't fail. The magic smoke didn't escape from your server hardware. Your ISP didn't disconnect you. The DNS servers didn't go down. You broke it, you ignored the fact that it was broken, you didn't communicate with us about it being broken, and you're buying us off with trinkets and baubles.

I know I can't get my money back. I can, however, stop paying you. I can stop recommending this game to other people who might pay you. I can warn other people who are thinking of paying you that they shouldn't. There's plenty of time to do something meaningful to make this right, so please take a minute to consider how you can do that.

Even if it means working a few extra hours, or over a weekend, or whatever. If you have to pay interns to come in and manually refund hero days to every hero who was in a town that got wiped out by your failure to do your jobs correctly, do it.

Also, perhaps recode your game so that if this ever happens again you can do something about it. This isn't rocket science, it's 1s and 0s. Do your jobs.

loam
ristoril,
There was a post made on the Twinoid news about the problem. (Though, the quality of the response *is* questionable).
Motion Twin is a very small company. You can learn a bit about how they operate here: http://motion-twin.com/ As they are in France, expect them to have 35 hour work weeks and plentiful vacations. The French are culturally different in a very significant way here to the Americans: they take time off from work. The French are given 30 days minimum of paid vacation time - compared to Americans who get 0 unless an employer decides to give them. I am a bit jealous, myself. Imagine if this bug had happened over the holidays! (Yes, Epoq isn't French but is working in France).
24/7 help is an unrealistic expectation to have here - or on any MT game.

As far as taking your money and not giving what they promised, I recommend a good read through of their Terms of Service here: http://support.twinoid.com/cgu

Yes, that says that they can interrupt your service anytime. They can modify their services at anytime. (Imagine logging in one day and Die2Nite is now a cleaning simulator).

If you're uncomfortable with the terms or the quality of the services being provided... you, of course, can make smart consumer decisions based on the terms/quality.

Sorry if this sounds snobbish or condescending. I just think a lot of people have put a lot of misinformation out there about MT and I tried to write this as helpfully as possible.

On april 27, 2012
Adzman

From Coro:

Since I'm not a Hero or a mod on D2N, let me tell you some info about warnings (feel free to post a quote in there)

All these things give a user a notification:

Warning a post (this can either append a warning to the end of a post, or replace a post with a warning)
Deleting (or recovering) a post or thread
Closing (or opening) a thread
Moving a thread

All of the above add an entry in your mod history, but there aren't any automatic things that happen if you have a certain amount of entries

And mods can't edit any post they want, they're limited to warnings (AFAIK)
On april 27, 2012
Adzman

Also:

Mods can't edit posts made by other people, unless it's the first post of a thread. They have the same editing limits as a regular user for their own posts

and

A mod can warn any post they want, which is a way to "edit" a post in cases where a post can't be edited

Could you please quit your childish nit-picking?

If you write a long-ish, relevant post and you slip in the occasional "u", chances are it's not going to be a problem.

If you repeatedly send short posts full of "u", it's not OK.

Besides, "you" hardly takes more time to type than "u". "u" is not a word and it's not an acronym. LOL is an extremely widespread and commonly accepted acronym. But that's not even the point. How many times do you need to say "LOL" in a day? And how many times might you need to use the word "you"?
"LOL" will arise on very few occasions and would not turn the forum into a txt fest. "U" is txt talk. You may not use txt talk on our forums.

Please note that it's not for you to agree or disagree with. It's the way it is.

I think that Epoq's post can be interpreted in too many ways. A lot of people could take it as saying that, potentially, anyone being mean to them might get in the way of their enjoyment of the game and that if you're not following what the town says or if you're playing selfishly and endangering others' life (in game obviously) you might be "trying to disrupt it".

Obviously these are completely wrong interpretations but people with less experience and not much knowledge of the game, its rules and its history / culture may (or may not) be inclined to think this way?

Basically, at the time Epoq wrote this, he was targeting people who were deliberately setting up accounts with the sole purpose of ruining every town they'd play in, and recruit others to join them and wreck every town and attack everyone on sight all the time for the sole pleasure of wrecking things and nothing more. They all got their accounts deleted, which was great.

Playing selfishly or being very annoying is totally A-OK and within the rules.
